text: Bottle from the brewery. Pours dark brown with a bubbly, frothy beige head. Tastes like chocolate malt, burnt toast, roasted coffee, and creamy with a hint of dried fruits. Light/medium body and low carbonation. Smells like chocolate malt, burnt toast, roasted coffee, dried fruits, and chocolate syrup.

August 25th, 2014 - Uintas looks like beef in a bottle. As I pour it, I accidentally utter "Oof, this looks beefy", both a comment on its muscular stature and the dark, brown color of the body and the slightly lighter color of the head. The aroma is extra creamy, giving off hints of steak sauce and soy sauce (notably, not teriyaki sauce), with hazelnut and nutella for sweetness. I go in again once the foam settles, but catch mostly the same, though richer, and clearer. I deliberately served it on the warmer side, which allows the flavor to deploy into action immediately. The alcohol burns bright, but settles once the hazelnut flavor comes into play. I also catch the flavor of virginia pipe tobacco, and in the aftertaste, a long, deep, festive flavor of roasted chestnut. Its a heavy beer, and definitely on the boozy side, which detracts from some of the potential for complexity, but some reappears near the bottom of the glass. The aftertaste adds some licorice and anise, a nice spicy finish, and a clean way to end a powerful, potent beer.

Back Log. I couldnt for the life of me remember what this beer was called when I drank it, but out of no where, bam Sea Legs. Thats what happens with age. Nice notes of bitter chocolate, roasted malts and coffee. A solid Baltic porter.
Black pour with a khaki head. nose is heavy chocolate, sweet, light vanilla and fruit. Great palate, smooth vanilla, light alcohol, sweet, sticky, and coffee notes.

Top score on appearance for a very resilient beige head, pours a dark brown, almost black with mahogany edges. Nice Aroma, chocolate bars, vanilla powder, dark roast and a little booziness. Very deep in terms of flavor, heavy malts, chocolate, charred wood, hints of mint. Lasting finish. Lovely.
Pours a nice dark, almost black, brown. Aromas of chocolate, espresso and a little licorice. Big flavor, chocolate, burnt coffee, with a nice little bite to it.
Pours cola brown with aroma of roasted malt, coffee, vanilla, and some chocolate. Roasted malt flavor with chocolate and vanilla sweetness and hint of coffee bitterness. Very nice.

Bottle 75 cl on December 31, 2015, thanks to Mirre (non ratebeer).Listed as 8.7% ABV as of the label, bottled 11/11/13.Black color, light brown head. Alcohol, malty, light smokey scent. Malty, alcohol, light bitter taste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness.
Aroma of coffee, roast, and chocolate. Creamy smooth and slightly dry. Tastes roasty and a little bitter. Black with a huge frothy thickly lacing tan head.
Could have more aroma. Its solid on its appearance. You can taste the oak and some amount of coffee
Bomber, room temperature. Pours a thick blackish brown. Smells of chocolate. Smooth taste, oak, chocolate. Finishes slightly bitter on the palate. Real easy drinking.
going from notes and not much detail. bottle date 11/14. Didnt enjoy nearly as much as the Labyrinth.. something was a little odd at end of flavor - too roasted? may try again?
Bottle. Pours a deep dark color with a coffee chocolate smell. Very intense flavorful taste. I really enjoyed ending my evening with this nice sipper
Very nice starter beer, pop this open then move to a growler of something not as refined.

With Z, a bomber, pours pitch black with a nice have tall head. Nose is heavy malt and hoppy Taste is heavy malt , with dark fruits and vanilla bean. Finish is dry, and ends on the same tasting notes with a short drinkable finish. Nice ! Quaff Score 7 / 10
Bomber. Pours black with a tan head and aroma of malt and liquorice. Taste is of malt, bourbon, dark fruits, liquorice, and slight hoppy notes into the roasted finish.
Really great. Strong roasted malt and coffee aroma. Beautifully dark with a 1-finger tan head. Smooth and weighty palate. Flavors were big and blalanced. Earthy malt with toast, chocolate and coffee.

How: Bottle..
Where: Tasting 2015-10-09, bought from Systembolaget.
Appearance: Dark brown colour with a beige head.
Aroma: Chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla, bourbon, some coffee.
Body: Medium body and carbonation.
Flavour: Chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt, bourbon, sugar.
Really nice. A dark brown color. A nice dark chocolate coffee aroma. Taste is a vanilla bourbon with some chocolate malts blended in.

From the corked, caged 750 ml. bottle. 2013 batch. Aged. Tasted on November 13, 2015.

Dark brown pour with huge tan had and some ruby red hues if you really look at it.

The aroma is not as chocolate and dark malt based as similar beers. I also don[t get a whole lot of smoke but it may have something to do with being 2 years old even though it is bottle conditioned. An odd sort of cherry fruit note though.

Smooth medium body mainly.

The taste tends to bring out a kind of fruity malt character with little bitterness. Everything about this might have been better 2 years ago

[7595-20150827] 750mL bottle. Light chocolatey malt aroma. Black body with a medium-lasting foamy tan head. Bitter dark roasted grains flavour has a long-lasting smoked wooden finish. Full body. Good. (8/4/8/4/16) 4.0
(w/ Big Red, blankboy, HogTownHarry, jercraigs)

Bottled from Systembolaget
Black with a huge, beige head. 
Vinous and slightly cereal aroma with sweet, dried fruits. 
Prune and raisins in the flavour. 
Soft and smooth.
Really tasty. A good porter that almosts tastes a little sour. Aging in the bourbon barrells suited it well.

[Bottle (750ml) shared with HogTownHarry, jercraigs & mabel -- c/o j&m] Pours a deep dark amber-brown with a huge lasting frothy beige head and some lacing on the glass. Aroma of chocolate, lightly roasted malt, yeast, light hops and some breadiness. Sweet, malty flavour along with light hops, some herbs and chocolate. Average to medium bodied. Pretty good.

Pours black with large persistent tan head. Great carbonation. Smells of chocolate malt no hop aroma. Has medium full body with chocolate strong malt presence hint of vanilla. I did not detect the bourbon

Draft at Uber, Seattle. Cloudy dark brown, lingering stringy tan head. Chalky, cocoa nib, dry and bitter. Odd coffee, great dry bitter. Quite tasty.

bottle @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Opaque brown/black color, brown head, stripes of lace. Taste is bittersweet toasted malt, light carbonation, and mouth-drying hops in the finish. Big taste, wouldnt take much to overfill me. Nearly works, but balance and flavor miss the mark.

Bottle at THT. Black with small off white head. Soft herbal notes with light coffee and roasted malts, some spices and dark chocolate. Medium sweet with soft roasted bitter notes. Medium bodied with slick feel. Decent.

Bottle at THT. Pours near black with a small beige head. Aroma of rich caramel, sweet malt, overripe dark fruits and raisins. Flavour is heavy sweet and moderate bitter. Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle at THT. Dark brown pour with tan foam. Aroma is roasty, black pepper, light cocoa, chocolate. Taste is desserty, chocolate cake, light vanilla. Palate is light, a bit light and watery but easy drinking.

Sampled from bottle @ Hey Julien is back and Deans floor is moist tasting. Opaque black color, average sized beige to light brown head. Smell and taste malts, roasted malts, some chocolate, bitter with a hint of dark sugar. Medium body and carbonation. Lovely.

Sample at September THT.
Thin creamy tan head. Clear deep amber pour. A very good baltic porter

Bottle at THT tasting. Black pour, thick tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, licorice, chocolate and sugary malts. Flavor is smooth, chocolate, caramel and sugary sweetness. Decent balance. A bit mild.
Bottle from the brewery, cellared two years. Awesome black color with thick tan foam. Porter front taste then chocolate with the oak and vanilla finish. Very smooth!

2015-08-26. Back body with a small tan head. 3+ Aroma of dusty dry malt, light roast and herbal notes. Flavour is interesting, dark malt, light herbal licorice touch, moderate dusty dark malt. Average plus bodied palate, good carbonation. Solid but the base malt is not quite rich enough for my taste today. Bottle cellared several months from Ye Old Spirit Shop, Frederick, MD. Overheard: "Whats a snozzcumber, exactly?""snozzBERRY... not cucumber."
Dark cola brown. Tinny cookie dough on the nose. Dilute, meh porter. Hints of something decent, but thats about it. Hints. (Lies!)

On 75cl bottle with Alexcg. Dark color, good foam. Medium/ high aroma intensity; roasted, malt, dried fruits & some
Licorice. Medium/ full body & high complexity. A little on the sweet side-
Some bitterness. Very enjoyable

75cl bottle shared by Alexcg, thanks! Pours dark brown with a modest beige head. Aroma of roasted malt with hints of bourbon, wood, spices and caramel. Medium sweet with nice, quite complex and rather flavourful with a mild bitterness. Fairly unusual, but quite tasty Baltic porter.

Pours a solid black with a tan head and lacing. It has a complex aroma of chocolate, bourbon, and some coffee and smoke. It has a mild flavor of chocolate and bourbon up front with a chocolate, bourbon, and smokey finish over a medium-heavy body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750ml from Systembolaget. Black with a creamy white head. Rosted malt aroma, dark chocolate, cream. Smooth mouthfeel mild aroma. Rosted maltw
 Coffee and fudge.

Pours an opaque black with a foamy khaki head that settles to a film on top of the beer. Copious amount of lace left around the glass as it goes down. Smell is of dark roasted malt, cocoa, bourbon, and wood aromas. Taste is much the same with lots of bourbon, hints of dark fruit, and cocoa flavors on the finish. There is a mild amount of roasty and woody bitterness on the palate with each sip. This beer has a lower level of carbonation with a slightly crisp mouthfeel. Overall, this is a pretty good beer, certainly worth a try."

750 shared poured a medium to dark brown with off white head. nice roasted malt nose along with the bourbon barrel and vanilla notes. the flavor was really good and as in the description the body is medium light which played perfectly with all the flavors. lots of bourbon, oak vanilla, roasted malts and chocolate. nicely balanced and delicious.

11/22/12 750ml bottle. Pours a near black with a thin, tan head. Aroma has great notes of roasted malts, dark chocolate, slight dark fruits, coffee, licorice, molasses, and peanut shells. Taste is balanced with awesome notes of roasted malts, dark chocolate, coffee, and a lingering, slightly smoky ending. Medium-full body with a medium carbonation. Clean in the mouth with a bone dry finish. Overall a great beer. Smooth roast, coffee, slight dark fruits, and a long finish.

Aroma has smoked almond and flowers. Odd, but true. Taste is too bitter, the Porter is missing a little balance in itself for the barrel aging and flavor. The mouth feel had a smoking burnt residual thing going on. A little claggy. Half of me loves this and half of me wants to pitch it because of the oddities going on. Whatever these are aged in are burned chicory and oak. Bottle.

750 ml bottle. Pours dark brown with tall, creamy, beige head and nice lacing. Aroma is of chocolate malt, dark fruit, bread crust and brown sugar. Body is full and smooth. Taste is of plums, toasted malt, coffee, brown sugar, dark fruit and some hops. Finish is long and dry. Very nice brew.

Almost black beer with brown hues and a medium, brown head. Strong aromas of cocoa and some booze. Tastes of roasted coffee, sweet dark chocolate, molasses, and hints of bourbon-like flavoring. Earthy and chewy mouth feel. Finish is of bitter cocoa. A bit smoky too. Very tasty and surprisingly easy to drink.
Bottle at home. Black beer with an beige/brownish head. Roasted chocolate vanilla woody earthy coffee and tar aroma. Roasted chocolate vanilla raisins bourbon flavour.
750 ml. bottle. Pours almost black with a nice tan head. Aroma of chocolate, malt, coffee, and bourbon. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, bourbon, vanilla, dark fruit, and oak. Very nice.

If you can find it, drink it, its delicious. Who cares what it looks like. This beer delivers on nose, flavor and palate. Last Sat drank a 750ml that has been in my cellar since last November. Have also tried fresh at the brewery.

Pours dark brown, fairly thick and turbid, with tan head that laces well. Nose is oaky bourbon, cacao,, black patent malt.. Tastes of patent malt, oaky bourbon, earthy brown sugary figgy fruit, cacao, vanilla. Finishes complex and velvety.

Pours deep dark brown with a good sized dense tan head. The aroma has cocoa, roasty malt, oak, cream, dark caramel, mild duds and a nice smooth richness to it all. The body starts quite smooth with frothy carbonation and this gets a light bit rough. The flavor begins with the aroma notes, but has more bitterness to the roast, some earthy hops, cocoa, mild vanilla and cacao nibs. The finish has a touch of bourbon and a smooth warming affect. Excellent beer.

A dark tea pour creates a black body with mahogany highlight at the stem of the glass, a tall two inch, frothy-smooth, light khaki head creates globs of erratic islands and peninsulas of lace

Well integrated aromas and flavors of robust chocolate-coffee fused with mellow marshmallow, vanilla, black tea, char, graham cracker, citrus, blueberry juice, raisins, dark cherry, almonds, caramel, faint bourbon notes and heat, all on a creamy, pillowy, coating medium body with tickling carbonation amplifiying the subtle spirit heat, a creamy-tacky residual offers the previously mentioned components over a solid drying influence with an oaky hue, medium duration with dark chocolate and coffee hanging on until the final moments while nuances of marshmallow and graham cracker swirl around, a touch of tobacco with dark chocolate smoors dipped in coffee

I was initially a bit underwhelmed with the intensity, yet am very much enjoying the well balanced robust-rich-dry complexities this offers as a result of the controlled components, especially as this warms into the 60s, another very solid beer from Uinta

750 ml cork and cage bottled on 11/10/14 served at 50° and warming into TeKu

Bottle pours black with tan head. Malty aroma. Taste malts, slight roast. molasses, caramel with moderate roast/hop/oak finish. Moderate palate. Average Baltic porter. I didnt get any bourbon character to speak of.

Pours a finger of tan head on a black body.
The aroma is roasted malt, vanilla, oak and honey.
The taste has mild coffee and pine bitterness throughout, roasted malt and chocolate sweetness. 
The texture is thick with low carbonation.
Nice and enjoyable.

On tap at PPD a while back, pours a deep brown with some creamy, off white head. Nose has quite a bit of caramel and brown sugar, some vanilla, molasses, burnt toast, some dark fruit notes. Flavor has just the right amount of barrel, some char and light smoke, lots of crusty burnt toast, vanilla, caramel, some dark chocolate. Full bodied, but thankfully dry. Well made.

Pours a dirt-brown stream that lands opaque black in the glass with big, fluffy khaki head. Big, predominantly malty and cereal aroma. Some truffles, morels, slight chocolate, a little smoke. Rather full bodied palate for 8%, impressive balance and complexity. The finish falls slightly short, but very good.

Bottled on nov 13 - 2013.
Aged in Bourbon Barrels for nearly 12 months and then bottled conditioned until today. ABV: 8%

Very dark brown beer with a huge three finger high, beigebrown head that leaves lacing on the glass.

Nose: Vanilla, oak, bourbon, coffee, whipped cream, honey, dark bread and roasted malt. Its a complex, beatiful nose!
Taste: Coffee, roasted malt, smoke, bourbon, dried fruit, red berries, a  hint of licorice, molasses, pine and caramel.
Body: Correct me if Im wrong but I think a Baltic Porter should have almoust a "thin" body and thats exacly what this beer has! Medium to light body with high carbonation. Beatiful complex texture. A little smokey feeling. Long, dry aftertaste with medium bitterness that works great with the sweet, malty taste. The ABV of 8% is very well hidden. 

Beatiuful, outstanding beer! Im absolutely in love!

Bottle aged from 11/12 bought in store. Hope it holds up fine. It did. Deep opaque brown pour with beige head. A complex, multi-faceted, fairly balanced high ABV beer. Notes of molasses, chocolate, coffee grounds, vanilla, bourbon and oak.
Dark. Thick. Creamy head. Quite complex and dynamic. Some vanilla. This is an excellent porter. Thanks for the recommendation vyvvy.

On tap at 33 West. I didnt have high expectations as Uinta has been pretty mediocre for me in the past, but I wanted a stout/porter and this was the most interesting option on the menu. Anyway, dark pour with a small frothy head. Chalky, milky aroma. Rich cocoa and milk flavor. Not much bourbon at all (? Which isnt necessarily a bad thing). Mild fruitiness. Lots of coffee and roast. I liked it.

Bottled, from Systembolaget.  Very dark brown, small beige head. Vanilla and mud cake up front. Sweet with full body and well rounded mouthfeel. Chocolate, sugar and vanilla. Bitterish finish with some heat and plenty of sugar. Too sweet.

Rated on 9-14-2013 at Fort Wayne, IN RateBeer gathering (Corked and caged bottle and bottled on 11/27/2012). The appearance is a small head with a lengthy retention, opaque dark brown body and spotty amounts of lacing. The aroma is lightly roasted, malt, chocolate, dark fruits, and some alcohol. The flavor is dark fruits, chocolate, malt, and alcohol. The mouthfeel is moderate carbonation and this beer is medium bodied. A most quaffable sipping beer that would make for a good cold weather beer. It is a beer worth trying.

An opaque dark brown with a creamy well sustaining head with good lacing. Aroma is subdued with just a bit of chocolate and roast. Mild vanilla and a nice high quality chocolate in the taste. Some roasty notes along with some wood and a smokey character. Finishes with a combination of hoppy and roasty bitterness that sort of builds. Semi creamy mouthfeel with a medium body and low carbonation. Good flavor and easy drinking. Well made.

2015 bottle. Pours dark brown with creamy tan head. Very light aroma of milk chocolate and some malt. Taste is Belgian chocolate with some lactose and a nice pine bitterness. Roasty with a little vanilla from the barrel. Medium mouthfeel.

Chocolate brown with ruby tones and well sustained ashen tan foam leaving lace. Aromas of booze, vanilla, smoke, and some dark berry. Gently bittersweet with slightly smokey finish. Medium bodied but holds pretty well as it warms. Ive been sitting on it for about 4 months.
An old beer, bottled in 2013. A little rough and musky, but still tasty. Good malt still coming through.

On draft. Appearance: deep brown and opaque, nearly black, with a moderate light brown foam head. 
Aroma: Pleasant mix of chocolate, vanilla, dark cherries, and a light roasted coffee.
Taste: Deep, rich toasty chocolate, molasses, and vanilla up front, giving way to a pleasantly light roast character and sharp but not overpowering hop bitterness. 
Mouthfeel: Moderate body, with light carbonation, and a warming alcohol bite on the back end. 
Finish: Bitterness and roast helps balance the strong sweetness of this beer, with a lingering chocolate and roast character. 
Overall: Really pleasantly surprised that the bourbon barrel aging added complimentary flavors instead of overpowering. Vanilla flavors help balance the chocolate and roast. Chocolate malt dominates the flavor profile as it should. Walks a fine line compared to an imperial stout, but this fits the style. Well done.

750ml thanks to Elise. Bottled November 2013, opened February 2015..I was a little bit worried about how it would hold up. Thankfully, it has done fine. Wow. Sublime. Easy drinking for the ABV, though you know in the warm sweet aftertaste their is some respectable alcohol. Smooth chocolate tones. This is pretty much an optimum Baltic Porter, with the vanilla bourbon tones throwing it over the top. Creamy, smooth on the palate. This really hit the spot. Great beer. Doughy brown chocolate.

This is a solid offering from Uinta, one of the better porters Ive had. Bottled on 10-28-13. Pours black with a nice tan head that starts thick and quickly thins out with decent lacing. Nose is chocolate, roasted malt, bourbon, oak, vanilla, slight smoke. Has a medium body and a very well balanced, complex flavor. Has a lively feel on the tongue, the hops are kind of spicy and the overall feel is dry yet very flavorful, slightly sour but plenty sweet. The oak, bourbon, and vanilla notes are especially nice, with slight licorice, raisin, and earthy tones. Highly recommended.

Dark chocolate, cola and charred wood in the aroma. Although it appears black, its actually a beautiful crystal clear dark brown and mahogany color with a very foamy medium tan head. All of the aromas show up in the flavor with the cola being pronounced which is perfect for a porter. Theres a nice licorice bite and an acrid burnt bitterness that balances out a mild sugary vanilla sweetness. The body is appropriately on the thin side with a bit of creaminess around the edges. The dry bitterness lays down on the tongue and stays there but not in an overwhelming way. The 8% ABV here is almost completely hidden which makes this dangerous. Finishes light and dry with a lasting bitterness and bittersweet/dark chocolate flavor. Excellent Baltic porter.

Pours black with a khaki head. Smoke, chocolate, caramel, malt, oak and vanilla aroma. Smoke, chocolate, vanilla, oak, malt, hop, dark fruit and slight spice flavors. Medium body and average carbonation. Smoke, chocolate, vanilla and oak finish.

A very good Baltic porter all around. Pours a thick black with a creamy tan head. Smells of vanilla, cinnamon and chocolate. Taste has lots of vanilla ice cream, with some chocolate coming in later. Some oak in the finish. Delectable. Had in the bottle.

Flaska från SB. Svart brun färg med stor smutsbrun skumkrona. Doft av mörk choklad, vanilj och ekfat. Söt fyllig kropp med lite vinkaraktär. Framträdande smak av choklad och ekfat. Lite rökig avslutning.

Bottle. Moderate toasted and dark chocolate for he malt, light herbs and earth for the hops and yeast, with hints of wood, charcoal and vanilla. Head is small, frothy turning wispy, khaki with fair lacing and good legs, and is mostly diminishing. Color is very dark brown. Flavor starts faintly sweet and lightly to moderately acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, slick, with a soft to lively carbonation. A plenty bold but still easy to drink Baltic Porter.

Poured into a perfect pint.

3.75 A: Black color. Three fingers of frothy light brown head. Retention is pretty good and a few whisps of lacing are left.

5.0 S: This has a world class nose. Powerful, complex, and well integrated. Moderate roastiness, but overall is quite sweet. Tons of tangy molasses with layers of chocolate and caramel. Hints of coffee and fig. I didnt list a lot of descriptors, but what I did list runs deep. 

4.25 T: The taste is very good, but cant compare with the nose. Layers of chocolate and caramel, moderate roastiness. Fig and maybe some currant and prune fruitiness. Like the nose, molasses is the focus.

4.5 M: Heavier medium to heavy body. Good moderate carbonation. Creamy with a slippery velvet texture. Super smooth.

4.5 D: Really great brew. Buy it for the taste, love it for the nose. This reminds me a good deal of Marshal Zhukov, which I adore.


DavoleBomb, May 29, 2013

Bottle poured a black hue w/ a large tan head diminishing to a lasting cap. Moderate molasses and cardboard aroma. Initial flavor is moderate sweet w/ a light bitter finish. Tastes are molasses, licorice, vanilla and musty cardboard. Full bodied and soft carbonation.

Big brown head. Opaque black body goes deep dark red at edge. Deep
chocolatey earthy aroma with roasty toffee notes. Sweetish faintly
acidic taste of earthy chocolate with funky pine needle notes.
Mid-to-full body. Mild, slightly flat, mealy mouthfeel. Sweetish
earthy mineraly dark chocolate aftertaste with burnt cocos notes.
Nice, drinkable, and full of flavour. Complex. (0.75l bottle from
wine monopoly Vika, Oslo.)
Dark brown with beige head. Aroma of roast malt, chocolate, vanilla and bread. Taste follows nose with noticeable alcohol. Very good, near great.

Bottle bought @ Systembolaget. Pours very dark brown with a big frothy brownish beige head that slowly dissipates while leaving lots of lacing and trace on the glass. Smell is slightly malty with roasted malts, toasted cereal, dark bread, vanilla fudge, charred wood, sweet liquorice candy, coffee, cocoa powder and soil. Taste is slightly sweet, bitter and malty with roasted malts, burnt caramel, vanilla fudge, charred wood, liquorice, coffee, chocolate, soil, brown sugar and hints of alcohol. Mouthfeel is soft, round, astringent and medium to full bodied. Finish is tiny sweet, bitter and malty with roasted malts, burnt cereal, burnt caramel, vanilla fudge, charred wood, coffee, chocolate, soil and alcohol. Tasty and surprisingly easy to drink.

Smells like a good porter should, some roasted notes, some hops..nice. It pours like it should as well, dark, black with a nice thick top that stays for quite a while.. The taste is full, again very much roast notes, a goo bitterness, not much alcohol, just a hint, a nice bloom with some hoppiness and chocolate , like it. Very full beer with a soft feel and long aftertaste..
 Overall a good Porter!
Not quite a Baltic, very significant chocolate and significant roast. Some hop in finish. A tad thin but very good drinkability.

Refrigerated 75 cl brown bottle corked and capped, bottled on November 27, 2012, poured into a snifter. Black with small dark brown highlight and small light brown head. Aroma is coffee, medium body, light carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is chocolate, ash, oak, smoke, some vanilla, some herbal hops, and some coffee. Complex, but not that good, may have been too old for me, not much bourbon, and too much ash.

Bottle:
Black, with a large, foamy, dark tan head.
Chocolate wine...bourbon aroma.
Smoky, barrel and chocolate taste.
Creamy, thick chocolate malt...roasted fudge and a trace of bourbon.
Very rich...almost too sweet, but the smoke reins it back in.
Excellent.
Sample at a local tasting event. Dark brown body with a low tan head. Chocolate, coffee, vanilla, caramel and a hint of wood.
Bottle (750). This is a great baltic porter with lots of deep roasted malt flavor.
Dark pour with good head and lacing. Lots of roast in this, and some bourbon to be sure. Tap at Snallygaster.

6 oz draft pour at Snallygaster 2014 shared by someone. Black with off-white head. Aromas of roast, chocolate, light caramel. Tastes of caramel, cream, vanilla, chocolate, light bourbon. Medium body with a dry finish.

Transfer from BA review on 5-5-13-

 Poured from bottle into a pint glass

 Appearance  The beer is served a deep brown color with a one half inch tan head. The head has a good level of retention, slowly fading to leave lots of lacing on the sides of the glass. 

 Smell  The aroma is heaviest of a roasted malt smell mixed with nice aromas of chocolate and coffee. Along with these darker aromas are some notes of a caramel sweetness mixed with a little bit of a vanilla and an oaky smell.

 Taste  The taste begins with roasted malt taste mixed with some sweeter tastes of caramel and a bit of light vanilla upfront. A light chocolate flavor quickly comes to the tongue with an oaky taste soon following mid way through the taste. The caramel sweetness dwindles more toward the end with the overall flavor of the brew drying out a bit as some roasted coffee and a more dark chocolate like flavor grow stronger. In the end, the roasted characteristics of the brew stand out rather well, leaving a dry and roasty flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the brew is on the average side with a carbonation level that is rather average to slightly above average producing a very easy drinking brew, although it may possibly be a little light for accentuating the darker flavors of the brew.

 Overall  A tasty and very easy drinking brew. There is almost no detectable alcohol taste even at 8 % abv. The nice roasted malt and drier finish of the brew make this one a quite delicious and a dangerous brew. Quite nice.

"Solid brew as are most of this crooked line. Barrel faint at first especially in the nose but it opens up well. Only fault is a little prickliness and slight overcarbonation. Dark fruits, roasted malt and barrel are well balanced and tasty. Nothing is really quite a 9, but there are a couple 8.5s so there ya go."

Pours the color of burnt caramel with a frothy head of khaki foam thats creamy and lays itself on top of the beer. When the glass is not too full you can see cola colored hues and honey golds. Lace is shimmering like sea foam in the bright moonlight.


Nose is lush caramel and a fainter molasses. Coffee, chocolate and roasty malt. A sultry whiff of sweet bourbon and a bit of vanilla. The malt is earthy and fragrant. Some elusive dark fruits seem to flash and fade but the one that lasts is a alight plum. 



Taste is dry roasty malt with its sweet underpinnings. washes over the palate with a surprising milky sweetness. Strong bitter coffee, dry bittersweet chocolate, subtle vanilla and tempting bourbon. There is a wood so light on this that it seems to be literally afloat, weightless on the beer. A slight warmth from alcohol as this one finishes crisp, dry, thinnish to the palate but with a medium mouthfeel and with some hop bitter to linger alongside all that smooth caramel.

Pours thick dark brownish black with a caramel head. Aroma brings light sweet bready and smokey notes. Flavors bring light roasted caramel malts and some nuttiness with a beautiful amount of chocolate as well.
(Bottle). Pleasant aroma and taste with good balanced flavorings from roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, hops and bourbon. Nice!

Bottle. Opaque black liquid with medium to big light tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, bread, light ash, grain and toast. Taste is light sweet and light bitter with notes of coffee, chocolate and bread. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Pretty nice.

Smells roasted malt and chocolate. Good sweet taste of chocolate, coffee and dark malts. Bitterness is good and right and taking hold throughout the mouth for a long time. Would this be a bit sweeter, I would have loved the beer even more. Follow me @ Kung av öl @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.

Pours an opaque beautiful black with abundant toffee head that laces nicely.

Aroma is mostly toffee with some chocolate that comes out more as the brew approaches room temperature.

Brew is a clean chocolate and coffee, with mild bitterness on the tip of the tongue yielding to the more roasted character as it clears the mouth. 

In all, a bold and respectable showing which, while not delivering much in the way of interest delivers as a strong porter.

Smak och doft choklad, kaffe, vanilj, söt laktris med rostade toner och aningar av trä och bourbon. Lagom sötma, rund och len, fadd med fin beska. Välbalanserad.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2013 Vanilla and bourbon greet the nose, with chocolate and fruit notes . Pours a healthy black with a mostly diminishing khaki head and clinging lacing. Bomber. Pours black with tan head. Aroma is chocolate and bourbon. Flavor is chocolate, malt, oak, and slight bourbon. Very nice.

Pours a deep, warm sable just a whisker above black with a fairly thick and somewhat persistent tan head. Aroma tempts with notes of licorice, vanilla and chocolate and a hint of bourbon. Bottle. Pours black with creamy brown head. Nose and taste of toasted chocolate malt, graham cracker, mocha pie, black licorice, burnt coffee, very light bourbon and cherry wood. Medium body.

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 11/21/2012. Pours pitch black color with a 2 finger dense tan head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of big milk chocolate, caramel, toffee, cocoa, roasted malt, toast, vanilla, oak, bourbon, light coffee, and roasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of roasted and dark malt notes with moderate barrel presence; and good strength. Taste of milk chocolate, toast, caramel, toffee, cocoa, roasted malt, oak, clove, vanilla, bourbon, light coffee, and roasted earthiness. Slight roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of milk chocolate, caramel, toast, toffee, cocoa, roasted malt, vanilla, oak, clove, bourbon, and roasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice balance and complexity of dark and roasted malt flavors with barrel presence; with good robustness and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a creamy, smooth, and slightly chalky mouthfeel that is good. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming noticed after the finish. Overall this is an excellent barrel aged Baltic porter. All around nice balance, complexity, and robustness of dark and roasted malt flavors with moderate barrel presence; and very smooth to sip on for 8%. A very enjoyable offering.

As I inch up on 5000 with some stellar beers ... heres another beauty.  Dark, brooding.  The aroma is pure sexuality .. rich with dark fruit, and even a little bit smoke. (#4999, 5/2/2013)

Draft @ Pizza Port Ocean Beach, Ocean Beach, CA. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and bourbon aroma. Roasted malty bourbon and chocolate flavor with hints of caramel. Has a roasted malty bourbon and chocolate finish.

Pours black with a tan head. Sweet molasses really stands out but also chocolate, vanilla and a hint of coffee. Not very bitter at all. Mostly sweet.

Bottle (Bottled on 12/04/12). Pours with a black hued body with a large brown head. Good retention and lace. Aromas are of roasty, dark fruit esters (plum, dates), light licorice, deep chocolate, dusty wood, light oak, minimal bourbon, vanilla. More oak than bourbon. Flavors are oaky, licorice, under ripe plums, roasty tobacco, ashy roast, moderately bready malt. Barrel character is low for a bourbon barrel aged baltic porter. Very high carbonation, medium to full bodied, warming.

Draft at oakquinox 2013.  Dark brown, near black pour, with a light tan head.  Chocolate, roast, earthy, molasses, light notes of coffee and plum, and light bourbon vanilla.  Pretty good, but the barrel character was not pronounced.

Poured a very dark brown, but clear enough to see some carbonation bubbles rising up along the edges of the glass. There was a tall thick and creamy tan head that lasted well and gave some light lacing. There are many different aromas and flavors to this beer, but the key things is mild and a nice blending of those. In the aroma there is chocolate, a light tartness, a hint of wine, vanilla and light bourbon. In the flavor chocolate was the primary flavor initially. There was a roasted smokiness, a touch of a mettalic taste, light vanilla and light bourbon. All the aromas and flavors were balanced very well to make a nice smooth drinking beer. The alcohol was hidden very well, just giving a nice pleasurable flavor.

750 ml corked bottle from Fischmans. Dated 5 months ago. Pours an opaque black with a tan head leaving spotty lacing. Aroma has chocoate and roast, with an increasing vanilla presence down throughout the glass. Taste is of roasted malts, dark chocolate and sweet caramel - with alcohol. Luxurious and rich texture. Smooth and easy, with alcohol. Not "baltic-y" at all; would describe as an imperial porter - due to the alcohol - without the roughness. Tasty. Finishes sweetly wood-y, with vanilla and some faint bitterness. A nice one. Like the Uinta stuff.

Dark brown, fluffy tan head.  Toffee, chocolate, cocoa, big bourbon barrel character, some toasty and nutty notes, a little dark fruit, roasty edge late.  Fairly highly carbonated.  Balanced and tasty.

On tap at the public house. Thick dark full of vanilla. Very smooth.  Would have been good with dessert

Bottles from Capones. Craft Ale House, Frank Smiths, and Blue Dog.  Pours dark brown, fairly thick and turbid, with tan head that laces well. Nose is oaky bourbon, cacao,, black patent malt.. Tastes of patent malt, oaky bourbon, earthy brown sugary figgy fruit, cacao, vanilla.  Finishes complex and velvety.

750ml bottle from Imbibe Wine. Nose is chocolate, vanilla, with hints of roast, bourbon, and coconut. Black with a big, heavy lacing beige head. Flavor is peppery, light bitterness and sweetness, with a very light bit of bourbon. Good but not great as the barrel characteristics are not very pronounced.

75cl bottle.  Large brown head atop black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, vanilla/Bourbon, some wood, milk chocolate.  Taste is moderately sweet, vanilla/oak/Bourbon, some milk chocolate.  Smooth medium body, some stickiness.

Bottle via beer world:  Nose is low and dark malty.  Some anise present as well.  Body is full and slick with wet wood and low bourbon tone.  Nuts and earth come thru first.  bourbon tones are lazy and mellow.  This Magnum went surprisingly fast.   I didnt get much vanilla or hop tone, but thats just me.  My cat approved of this beer by sticking his entire paw into the brew and then lazily licking it off his fur.   He then took a nap.

Not a bad encounter from Uinta!  The chocolate and roasted features are there as advertised, but so is a considerable leather and earth presence, which is not my favorite aspect of this one.  Bourbon and vanilla flavors are there in nice proportion.

Draft @ Oakquinox 2013. Black in color with a khaki head. Nose of roasted malt, dark fruits, licorice, and ash. Decent chocolate, coffee, and molasses notes. Dont get much bourbon/barrel character. The flavor is a touch acidic. Moderate malt sweetness of caramel and molasses. Licorice, dark fruit, minimal bourbon, and some ash. Decent coffee and dark chocolate notes, too.

Black with a large tan head. Aroma is chocolate with a slight bit of earthiness. Flavor is chocolate with a bit of spice, somewhat reminiscent of a mole sauce. Very warming with a nice bittersweet finish.

Wife: 4.6

Bold aroma of chocolate and roast, with just a hint of bourbon.  Pours an opaque black, with a huge milk chocolate colored head.  The bourbon and oak come through a little further in the flavor, blending in with roasted flavors of the beer.  Theres very little hop presence that I can detect.  Very smooth and drinkable, with a full creamy mouthfeel.  This is a very impressive beer, and I will be getting more of this.

750mL bottle. Pours an opaque deep dark brown-black with a decent, mocha colored head, excellent retention and lacing. Nose is roasted barley, bourbon, dried fruit.  Mouth is thick and oily, semi-sweet up front with bourbon barrel, roasted barley coffee, vanillla and chocolate notes, malt. Finishes bittersweet. Very nice.

Bottle @ home picked up at Wilburs Fort Collins. Pours a deep brown appearance with a dark brown head. Really a nice bourbon, vanilla oaky, light coconut, sweet dark chocolate aroma. Initially, theres some fruity notes that are then surpassed by dark chocolate, roasty malts, mild bourbon, light woody flavor with a bit sweet, chocolate finish. The bourbon is tame but nice. One of my favorite offerings from Uinta thus far.
Poured from a 750ml bottle. Big chocolaty, coffee, smoky, malty, beer. Very nice, I am enjoying the subtle smoke. Very nice.

750ml bottle in snifter. Pours pitch black with a 1 finger tan mocha head which dissipates to a nice cap. Aroma was fairly strong with notes of vanilla, oak, brown sugar and chocolate. Taste is similar to the aroma, roasted malts and milk chocolate are at the front and are followed by an earthy vanilla caramel flavor. Hop presence is noticeable at the end also along with a slight alcohol bite. Creamy beer, medium body and light to medium carbonation with tight bubbles. A really enjoyable Baltic Porter, one of the best I have had, well balanced with great flavors.
Bottle. Pours a pitch black with a huge mocha head. Aroma is wood and dark booze. Taste is burnt chocolate with lots of smoothing vanilla. Lots of residual sweetness.

Draft. Poured a clear dark brown color with an average frothy tan head that mostly lasted and produced excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy roasted coffee, dark chocolate and woody bourbon aroma. Medium to full body with a dry smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy roasted malt, bourbon flavor with a medium to heavy bourbon sweet finish of moderate to long duration. This is the good brew.

A - pours opaque cola brown with huge fluffy tight bubbled tan head. S - strong cocoa powder and milk chocolate straight away. Notes of coffee grounds, vegetal and toasted malts, leather, and astringent. Some smoky notes.0 M - medium full body, relatively full palate. Very metallic. Dry ending. High carb. Watery mf. T - cacao powder, mocha, and carob, coffee up front. Toasted malts, dry grasses, over ripe apples,  light oak notes on the palate. Lingering sweet malty end. Bottle. Dark brown beer with a tan head. Rich malt and light vanilla aroma with light toffee. Rich malt and light toffee flavor with cocoa. Medium-plus bodied. Rich malt and light toffee linger with cocoa, light vanilla, and light oak.

Another fabulous beer from Uinta in their Crooked Line series. Poured this one at a good temperature with an enormous, foamy, thick, creamy, fluffy, tan head that settles so slowly and good lacing. UPDATED: FEB 17, 2015 Thanks to Aaron for this. Lovely stuff. Vanilla, and boozy with subtle woodiness. A little smokey. Smooth very drinkable for the complexity. Serving: Bottle

Draft @ The Ale House in Amesbury. Pitch black with lasting tan head that laced the tulip until finish. Aroma is chocolate, oak and light coffee. Taste is chocolate, vanilla and mild espresso notes. The oak is very light and subtle in this brew. Hints of molasses and sugar. Some burnt malts. Body is more on the full side with a drier smooth semi-sweet finish. Its really good. Just falls short of being great. Well worth a try if you ask me. I would order this again in certain circumstances.
Overpriced bottle at Freakin Frog. Slight chocolate to this porter. But aroma doesnt give off chocolate so much as something else. Slight roast. Creamy.

On tap at Mekong.  Poured black with a good very light tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, vanilla, faint bourbon.  Flavor is chocolate, espresso, vanilla, and more woodsy bourbon notes.  Medium body, quite smooth on the palate.  Nicely done baltic porter, and the bourbon aging gives it an interesting twist.  Quite good.

Bottle sample at the Uinta tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 2/7/13. Darkest brown in color with a thick tan head. Aroma of brownies, roast and oak. Malty, chocolatey and roasty flavor with a bit of sourness before a roasty finish.

Aroma brings wood, oak and toffee to the nose. Very fine black appearance with a large three-finger foam. Extremely complex flavors with coffee and mocha upfront and a genius chalky cocoa, toffee, oak, caramel and nougat combination for the base. Finish is a fantastic off dry boozy burn. Overall, this boasts genius complexity with a touch of bourbon notes. Full, rich, decadent. Id give this an A+ rating.
black color, aroma of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, same flavors, some dark fruits, ash, earthy notes, pretty enjoyable
750ml Bottle purchased from Beercraft. Pours very dark with minimal head. Some burnt flavors.

Tap. Pours opaque black with a large brown head and nice lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee. Flavor is the same plus chocolate and a bit of wood, perhaps a touch of vanilla. Medium sweet, light bitter, light woody astringence. Full body, creamy mouthfeel. Nice, but not a lot of taste from the barrels

Dark pour with a great tan head.  Loaded with a big chocolate nose with a background of cherries and dark fruits.  Full creamy palate.  Intense roasted malts mixed with bitter chocolate.  Bourbon far in the background.  A mellow sweetness with full developed flavors.  Very enjoyable.
Bottle from alexsdad06.  Pour opaque black with thick tan head.  Nose some roast, char almost grilled smell, and some brine.  Taste of roast, coffee, malt, but added character of slat and faint smoke
Black pour, small brown head. Faint roasty aroma. Deep chocolate dark fruit flavor. Complex and delicious.

750ml bottle - $12.99 at Bullocks Wine & Spirits in Marietta, Georgia.

Bottled On: 11/21/12.

Appearance: Pours an onyx black body with an initially tall, tan head, though it collapses fairly soon.

Smell: Fudge, carob chips, flecks of charred malt. Then, some vanilla and oak from the barrel. Light, leafy touch from the hops. Hint of foiled dark fruits, a bit of musty, funkiness cut from razor thin sniffs of alcohol.

Taste: Bittersweet chocolate, carob, and some slightly burnt malt hinting at espresso start. Medium-light sweetness. Slight, somewhat subtle vanilla and oaken elements from the barrel treatment. Theres a very, very light but noticeable funkiness for me, giving it a faintly sourish backing. Soiled dark fruitiness. Mild hop character, very low bitterness. Warming, chary, chocolaty finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium-plus carbonation, initially. Smooth, as it glides across the tongue, but theres ample suds all the same (initially, at least).

Overall: A decent sipper. I think I like it. I think?

Bottle.

Head is initially large, frothy, brown, mostly lasting.
Body is black.

Aroma is moderately malty (horse feed, wort, cereal, caramel, chocolate syrup), with a note of vanilla.

Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter, slightly unclean, slightly husky.

Medium to full body, creamy/syrupy texture, soft carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

Really hard to get past the terrible malt...very raw/worty/vegetal.  There are some nice elements behind that struggling for your attention, but they cant compete.  Almost drinkable in the mouth, but again the aftertaste reminds you of the dirty/clunky malt.  A nice idea, but poorly executed.

On tap@ Tribes alehouse in Tinley Park. 13 oz. snifter. Jet black with minimal khaki head. Aromas of dominate chocolate,some candied sugar. Taste like the aroma, chocolate, slight maltiness in the middle,  very smooth & drinkable.  Love it. Gonna have another one. ;-)
Draft. Dark maroon color, beige head, decent lacing. Aroma of vanilla, figs, cocoa. Taste has roasted cocoa, dates, slight edgeof smoke. Tasty stuff.

750 bottle.  A dark black brown pour with large beige head.  Smell is chocolate,  vanilla, dark malts.  Taste is cocoa, vanilla, medium sweet, some oak and faint char.  The body is a bit thin and the flavor is somewhat subdued, but very smooth sipper.  Still pretty nice offering.

Dark and murky with a nice finger of foam. Deep chocolate and expresso aroma but little oak or bourbon in the aroma. Plenty of wood and coffee on the tongue. Dried dark fruits show up the the long finish. Medium body. Decent alcohol presence.

On tap at Lunar Brewing Co., and snifter served displaying a black/brown color, frothy, brownish tan head foam, and very coating/sheet-like lacing. The nose was unusual. Not really roasty at this point, but more sweet grain/biscuit, vanilla, cocoa, and hints of cask wood. The flavor then expressed some roastiness with cocoa, a touch of dark fruit sweetness, and mellow alcohol/bourbon that awakened upon warming. Medium to full bodied, lightly syrupy, but rich & smooth.

The pour is a perfect black with a mocha head that leaves nice lacing. The aroma is surprisingly faint for the style with nothing really standing out. The taste is also strange. Its kind of sour & sweet & really lacking bitterness. Strange for the style but still decent overall.

750ml bottle.  oily black pour with a very large, fluffy, whipped brown head.  aroma hints at oaky vanilla note with milk chocolate roasted malts.  a bit more carbonated than i prefer, with a medium body.  flavor has notes of milk chocolate, oak barrel, hints of vanilla, caramel, and toast.  there is a light distracting funkiness probably from the barrel.  solid, but not my favorite in the awesome crooked line series.

Draft offering...interesting Baltic porter that was quite drinkable..not really getting heavy bourbon as expected..this was enjoyable yet it was a bit thinner than anticipated..not as much of the typical porter features of the style..

Aroma of strong oak, vanilla, cocoa and espresso.  Pours black with an out of control head.  Taste is waaaaay too oaky.  The vanilla and coffee are there but I feel like Im sucking it out of wood chips.
Tap at Cincy Beerfest. Smoky chocolate aroma. Black brown with a small tan head. Earthy coffee, chocolate, and ash flavor. Medium body, moderate carbonation.
Draft.  Light chocolate malt aroma.   Brown-black with small head.  Very sweet chocolate syrup and malt flavor.  Okay but a bit cloying.

Thin, dark body, average head.  The aroma is sweet and smokey.  The bourbon quality is present as a rich vanilla, and the smokey malt qualities had a nutty, bready character that just worked perfectly with the oak.  Id suggest this as a great starter for anyone whos interested in bourbon barrel aged beers, its very smooth and very sweet, but not at all subtle.  Of the beers I tried that were _new_ to me, this is the one Ill most certainly add to my own regular rotation if I can find it.

Bottle pours with a deep mahogany body that supports a mocha looking head of foam. The aroma offers up dark roasted malts, burnt malts, some earthy maltiness and faint dark fruity esters off in the background. The taste is rich inviting goodness coming from the likes of dark roasted malts to burnt malts and then moving into chocolate and earthy malt goodness. This is just rich and deep and fudge brownie yum. I get faint sweet dark fruity esters echoing away far off in the distance. Yummers!

Very very good beer.  Pours dark, slight head, mild carbonation.  It has a really good roasty, smooth body with an easy finish.  Not much hop at all, and its not needed.  I would also note that the barrel aging hasnt overwhelmed the beer.  A very good sipper.

750, corked and baled. Starting to think this whole series will be consistently great to amazing. Pours black with a sudsy dark tan head and plenty of webby lace. Big sweet chocolate and vanilla nose. Creamy medium body with very soft carb, goes a little watery in spots actually. Chocolate, vanilla, light bourbon, very soft woody notes in the background. Really a nice BP.

Charred oak, coffee, and prune nose, with an emphasis on the latter. Black, thin tan head. Prune and charred oak flavor, maybe some fudge. Medium bodied, smooth, and drinkable.Alcohol only noticeable on the back end and not excessive. No bourbon detected, which is a plus for me. Fairly simple, but solid.

25.4 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a thick and foamy tan head.  Nose is chocolate, plum, molasses and oak.  Rich and creamy with a sharp tang.  Taste is milk chocolate, black walnut, caramel, earth, wood and faint bourbon.  Satisfying, easy drinker.

A really solid Baltic porter.  Not a big wow factor and I didnt get the bourbon or vanilla notes at all but tasted quite good.  Poured a jet black with a bit of a roasted aroma to it.  Very smooth on the palate

This beer has a very rich dark brown color. A mild aroma hides the strong complexity of this beer. It has a roasted malt flavor which helps to temper the hoppy bitterness.

750ml, caged and corked bottle. Poured a dark brown with an off white head. Aromas of roast, chocolate, floral, wood, and a trace of bourbon. Tastes of wood, vanilla, chocolate, some earth, light bourbon, and some dark fruits.

Love this beer!  Interesting and different to me. I taste a string bold porter with a after taste of some sort of whiskey. I love this and it's different to me. In will buy this again.

750 bottle poured at home with a thick creamy tan head. Great smooth and silky mouthfeel that coats my whole mouth with flavor. Bittersweet chocolate and coffee with hints very subtle vanilla and coffee. A very light bourbon finish. Great beer.

On tap at Bottle Bar, pours pitch black with small white head, wasnt lasting. Aromas of roast, light chocolate, hops. Taste of plum and other dark fruits, wood, roasted malts, bourbon and a fair amount of hops. Finishes a little bitter and def warming in the body.
Chocolaty aromas. Pours black with a tan creamy head. Chocolaty, vanilla flavors. Overall a very very good porter.

On draft at Lizardville: poured blackish brown, sandy head with decent lacing. Nose is subtle bourbon barrel, plum, raisins, milk thistle. Quite smooth with roasted malts, plum/ raisins, subtle sweetness and BB. I'm a fan as the bourbon doesn't overwhelm and this is how a Baltic should taste

Rich and viscous piceous black pour with two fingers of crackling dark tan head.  Toasted wood and bitter chocolate in the nose,  notes of burnt sugar and black strap molasses. On tap at the Alehouse.  
Pours an opaque black with a thin beige head.  Aroma is cocoa, salty smokiness, bourbon, toasted oak.  Thick, creamy mouthfeel.  Flavor is dense chocolate, brine, bourbon, a hint of dark fruit sweetness.  Pretty tasty.

Location/Date:Bottle on January 26th, 2013 during day 2 of Nerd Beer Epic Weekend.
Appearance: Pours a black opaque. 
Aroma: Aroma of vanilla, bourbon, faint roast. 
Taste: Light bitterness, vanilla, bourbon but not too strong, roasty.   
Palate:Medium body.
Summary: Yet another great Uinta Crooked Line series beer - and a style I like too! This was  really a nice beer, hope to buy again - although I did see a bunch at TW McLean the day before we started drinking this.

750ml c&c bottle from the brewery 
Appearance: Pours dark brown with a big foamy tan head and lots of sticky lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, dark bitter chocolate, bourbon and vanilla 
Taste: Roasted malts, bourbon, vanilla with a bitter pine finish 
Very nice and smooth.
Nearly black in color with a light brown head.  Im getting lots of plums, prunes, molasses, chocolate, roast, charred wood, asphalt, raisins, and a touch of smoke.  Not bad, not amazing.

Almost-opaque black. Persistent mocha froth holds beautifully. Very sweet nose of wort, paint, soy sauce, cola, lactose, overripe plums, and stewed black cherries. Suggestive butter toffee, vanilla taffy, coconut, and licorice. Some vegetal notes poking through, as well. Snug but fuzzy carbonation. Initially tangy with metallic malt coupling with overripe plum sweetness and cooked tomatoes. Quite worty, and severely dull, consequently, as soggy, day-old breakfast cereal blends with flabby sugars to render any vivid malt remnants utterly lifeless. Worty to the point of resembling dog food, as well. Medicinal effect is apparent from the combination of higher alcohols and pervasive overripe dark fruits. Dusting of tannins gently brush the tongue, but quickly give way to a scorched wood and stale coffee grounds huskiness. Severely muddled, throughout. Finishes perpetually sugar-laden and unfinished, with a profound absence of malt definition and sturdiness of structure. A clear miss for Uinta, as this is quite the sugar and soy sauce bomb, with a host of other flaws piled on for good measure. Almost too undrinkable to analyze. A rather foul concoction.

text: 750 corked and caged bottle. Bottled on11/21/12. Pours a thick, tiny bubbled,  well retained light beige head, with some lacing, over a black (SRM 40) body.....nose is coffee, lighter chocolate, cocoa, hints of Bourbon, slightest hints of vanilla.....taste is a  slightly sweet brown sugar/molasses, with very light dried fruits including plum, raisin, light coffee, cocoa, light Bourbon, hints of vanilla, finishing with a mild bitterness....mouth feel medium, slightly sticky, lightly astringent, alcohol hidden, carbonation low. This is a nicely balanced beer, and in addition, the Bourbon, has been used with a relatively light hand. adding complexity without dominance. It is a bit on the dry side for a Baltic, and the dried fruit character of the malt backbone is light. The dominant aromas and flavors are of the more heavily roasted malts. BJCP 8/3/14/4/7

Location: Bottle at Nerd Beer Epic Weekend, 1/26/13


Aroma: The nose is roasted mats, bourbon, toast, brown sugar, molasses, and a hint of chocolate

Appearance: It pours a dark brown color with a light brown head and some drippy lace

Flavor: It has a dry, malty flavor with plenty of roast, and noticeable but not overpowering bourbon

Palate: The body is mid-full, it has an average carbonation, mild heat, and a dry, roasty finish

Overall Impression: 
This one works quite nicely.  Theres noticeable bourbon in the right balance with plenty of malt.  It isnt super sweet thanks to some dry, roasty components.  Overall, this one is quite good.

75cl bottle: pours a mostly opaque black with dark ruby mahogany edges and a large creamy beige froth of head that leaves fine lacing behind as it subsides. Has a sweet dark caramel and molasses nose with hints of smoke and chocolate. Starts with good fullness and fine carbonation with sweet dark caramel and chocolate malts, notes of plums and a subtle roastiness and mild noble hop bitterness before a drier smooth semi-sweet finish. Very true to style, complex and certainly drinkable.

Tap at Rustico Alexandria. Pours a clear, deep ruby cola. No head really. Nose is paper, tomato, black pepper, thick candy syrup, licorice. Taste is thin, sweet, some tea, seasoned tomato, mild dry cocoa powder. Not my thing.

Bottle. Black with a thick creamy tan head. Sweet, earthy, and somewhat musty aroma of chocolate, vanilla, and cereal grain; the aroma becomes increasingly phenolic as it warms.  Velvety medium bodied palate.  Taste of sweet milk chocolate, vanilla, and cereal grain with some notes of plastic and a lightly bitter, slightly oaky finish.  Disappointingly, Im not getting any bourbon out of this one.

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, cork opened with a pop.  Thick black pour with creamy tan, aroma brought notes of nice cocoa powder, vanilla, bourbon, and lots of oak come through, some coffee, roast, hints of slight caramel, toffee, and molasses, hints of dark fruits, and some slight smoke but pretty restrained.  Taste is a mix of sweet caramel, toffee, lots of dark fruits and anise, hints of roast, slight bourbon, lots of dry oak, there is a slight smoke note in there that manifests as it opens up, finishing fairly sweet, slightly bitter. Pours black with a big, frothy dark tan head that lasts a long time.  Aroma contains chocolate, vanilla, roasted malts, caramel, and some slight smoky impressions underneath.  Taste is dominated by a rich dark chocolate flavor.  Along with that roastiness, I get vanilla, some raisin, and a little bit of coffee also. While I cant place this among my favorites, it is definitely solid.

Pours mahogany-tinged black into an English pint. Mocha head with medium retention recedes leaving spider lacing. Dark caramel, chocolate and soy aromas. Medium bodied with chocolate and licorice upfront turning to earthy espresso in the lasting finish.
Bottle from Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours near black with a massive tan head and a treacle aroma. There is a dark molasses and bitter chocolate flavor with some anise and a dry finish.
Bottle shared by Marcus. Color is black with Brown head. Lots of lacing. Aroma is roasted malts. Taste is light chocolate with a little coffee.

750 ml caged and corked bottle, bottled on 12/04/12.  Served in a nonic pint glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with about an inch and a half frothy tan head that stayed around for a very long time.  Theres also a good amount of lacing.  The aroma is nice, it smells like dark fruit, roasted malt, bittersweet chocolate, wood, vanilla, and some coffee.  It tastes like roasted malt, bittersweet chocolate, vanilla, coffee, burnt/charred malt, dark fruit, molasses and a bit of licorice.  Nice balance between the sweet and bitter roasty flavors.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its smooth and a bit creamy with good carbonation.  I liked this brew a lot, I think Ill have to pick up another bottle soon.  $11.99 a bottle.

Serving: four ounce sampler from tap at Beer Junction.

Aroma: couldnt detect any aroma.

Appearance: no head (perhaps because it was a sampler).  Dark-brown body.

Taste: sour, woody, initial flavor with hints of alcohol and lightly bitter finish with long duration.

Palate: full body, dry texture and lively carbonation.

Overall: disappointing but would try again.

On tap at Beer Junction Barrel-Aged Beer Week. Black pour, low head, very light aroma. Flavor is light malt, with subtle roasted and chocolate notes, but its very mild. I really prefer something more substantial in a barrel-aged porter. Not one I would need to try again.

Bottle - 750mL corked and caged. Black pour with a tall, dense, frothy brown head. Roasted malt, soft vanilla, hints of chocolate, burnt caramel, dark fruit notes and toasted grains in the nose. Taste is big chocolate, roasted malt, soft coffee, vanilla, caramel, toasted grains, soft booze and notes of dark fruit. Body is medium-full with a dense carbonation and mild stickiness. Soft warmth as well. Ends with more chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruit, light booze, vanilla, and light coffee. Tasty!

On tap @ Public House in Vegas. Very dark brown with mahogany highlights. Meaty broth malty nose with seductive bourbon sweetness. The palate opens sweeter than expected, given the nose: vanilla, light smoke, sweet figs, molasses, bread crusts. Made me pay attention in a good way! Awesome!

text: 750 c&c from The Davis Beer Shoppe. Cork print is "Earth, Wind and Beer". Pours a nice dark brown with a 4 finger creamy darkish tan head. Aroma of very smooth dark malt with very subtle, but strong, darkish fruit. I keep thinking bourbon, then I read the description. So. Bourbon. Full bodied. Flavor is very bourbon/vanilla with lots of dark fruit and something that makes me think of the old, dry gingerbread crackers. Meanwhile the head is collapsing into degenerate, random lacing.  Its not exactly dry, but the various flavors tend to hide the malty sweetness. OMFG. JTDC. My head is expanding exponentially.

750 ml bottle to oversized snifter (shared with the Mrs.; thanks douglas88).  Looks good; black with foamy beige head.  Smells of semi-sweet malt and booze with some bitterness.  Tastes like it smells, only better, with notes of chocolate.  Good on the palate.  Good stuff!

750ml bottle, shared. Black color, good thin light brown head, leaves great full lace. Some chocolate, toasted malts, maybe some tobacco in the nose. Lightly smokey, toasty flavor. Again with the herbal, and tobacco notes. A bit less heavy on the dark fruit than other baltic porters can be, and I personally prefer that. Good roasty malts, solid bitterness, light sweet. Nice roasty chocolate aftertaste, just a hint of dark fruit, good light bit of smoke. Bigger body, smooth lighter carbonation, dry finish. Influence from bourbon barrel is subtle - not immediately obvious, but vanilla and wood flavors are noticeable. though no boozy heat. A nice balance. I think this is well done.
From a bottle poured a dark brown color with a small amount of head.  Strong sweet malty flavor with a lasting finish.

Appearance from the tap is immaculate.  Rich creamy head that lingers. Mild aroma. Good porter taste. Not too overpowering of any one kind of flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On draught at Roscoes. Deep dark porter almost feels like a stout. Barrel aging imparts rich boozy aftertaste.

Bottle @ The BeerMongers on New Years Eve...  Poured deep, jet black with a easy forming, eggy, off-white head.  A nice drinking Baltic Porter.  Smooth, clean, well rounded.  Not too cloying or thick of a mouthfeel.  Nice notes of cherries and other dark fruits with vanilla, worty malts, caramel cream, and a faint oak booziness.  Not too oaky or woody.  Definitely seemed to have been blended out a bit.  A great beer.  If it was about $2-3 cheaper it would make for a great buy.

Big bottle. Pours a thick black color with a thick tan head on it. I found it slightly bitter with just a hint of roasting in there. The feel of it was a tad harsh, but it was a very interesting drink.

Bottle. Colour...basically black with a thick tan head. Nose...oak, vanillin, toffee. Palate...creamy though not esp thick. Lots of oak and some smoke with an ashen/char aspect that exists throughout the palate. Theres plenty of chocolate, as well, but in a subdued manner that just happens to be omnipresent through the experience.

750 ml, corked and caged. Cool label. Pours a pitch black color with a medium, very creamy brown head. An interesting nose of bourbon, roast, metallic notes, anise. The flavor is great: sweet vanilla, bourbon, roast, mellow fruit, a gentle creamy palate. Coca. A bit of cola in the finish and more vanilla. Very decadent. Awesome. The palate is amazing.

Bottle. Pours deep, dark brown with thick frothy beige head; good retention and lacing. Aroma is roasted and caramel malts, cocoa, earthy hops, figs, light smoke, oak, and mixed nuts. Flavor is roast malt forward with good dark fruit esters and earthy hops (light bitterness); dry, roasted finish. Medium body and low carbonation.

Bottle.  Pours opaque with a large, frothy tan head, long retention with very good lacing.  Aroma is chocolate, roast, and dark caramel malt, dates and figs, earthy hops and fresh oak.  Flavor is velvety and silky chocolate, lightly roasted and caramel malt, light hops and bitterness with dark fruity esters, and a clean, sweet finish.  Full body and medium carbonation.
